title-group.article-title: The Power of One and Two Sample t-Statistics Given Event-Induced Variance Increases and Nonnormal Stock Returns: A Comparative Study

abstract.p: Accurate assessment of the statistical significance of abnormal returns is critically important for financial research. We compare the statistical power of test statistics in the presence of variance increases and nonnormal stock returns. We extend prior research in four important ways. First, variance increases are allowed to vary randomly cross-sectionally. Second, critical values for determining rejection regions are based on sample distributions under the null hypothesis. Third, pairwise comparisons of the statistics are made, and maximum power advantages are calculated. Fourth, two sample test statistics are examined in addition to one sample statistics. We find that test statistics should be based on standardized abnormal returns. For one sample tests the standardized cross-sectional test appears best, while for two sample tests the standardized residual and Wilcoxon tests are best.
